Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: William F. Thompson (North Carolina State University)

CoPIs: George C. Allen and Linda Hanley-Bowdoin (North Carolina State University), Robert Martienssen (Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory) and Matthew W. Vaughn (University of Texas at Austin, the Texas Advanced Computing Center).

Senior Personnel: Pete E. Pascuzzi (North Carolina State University) and David A. Micklos (Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory)

Epigenetics, the study of structural or chemical modifications of chromosomes that affect how genetic traits are expressed, is an exciting new area of biology. However, very little is yet known about the processes that transmit these structural or chemical modifications - known as "epigenetic marks" - through the multiple rounds of DNA replication and cell division that are required to make a plant or animal. Understanding this cell-to-cell transmission requires understanding events occurring only during the small part of the cell cycle in which DNA is synthesized ("S-phase"). In this project, the tools and knowledge from a previous NSF-supported project will be used to study transmission of epigenetic marks through S phase in two important model systems - maize and Arabidopsis. The results are expected to be relevant to most plants and animals. Millions of plant cell nuclei will be isolated and then sorted into groups depending on how much DNA they contain using a technique called flow cytometry . This sorting technique will provide material for a genome-wide analysis of epigenetic marks at each of several stages in the DNA replication process. Studying the sequence of events through the replication cycle will help to understand the molecular mechanisms that lead to formation active or inactive structures at different places along a chromosome. Similar techniques applied to mutant plants with known defects in chromosome structure or function may help highlight even more subtle control mechanisms. The results are expected to provide a better understanding of how genes are affected by structural and chemical modifications of DNA and the chromosomes in which it is housed. Understanding these epigenetic influences will have a profound impact on both basic and applied plant biology. For example, many crops are propagated clonally, and the occasional occurrence of "sports" (epigenetic variants) can impact both yield and quality. Another example involves crops engineered by gene transfer, which often experience unexpected inactivation, or "silencing", of the transferred gene. Silencing greatly complicates the process of obtaining commercially viable plant lines. This project will contribute to the ability to predict, and perhaps to control, gene silencing, which will be of considerable value for a wide variety of applications.

The project will bring together investigators with expertise in biochemistry, molecular biology, genetics, genomics and bioinformatics, and support a productive collaboration between two major research institutions. An excellent training environment for graduate and postdoctoral students will be provided, and selected undergraduates will participate in various aspects of the research. There will be two principal outreach efforts. A successful "Science in a Suitcase" unit on Genetics for middle schools, created during a previous PGRP project, will be updated, and teacher workshops will be extended to include many more teachers and students. In addition, a program in epigenetics will be inaugurated at the Dolan DNA Learning Center. This program will target advanced high school students and faculty at two year and agricultural colleges, and will provide valuable resources for teaching about epigenetics. A combination of web materials and podcasts, as well as resources for experiments, will be created. Public access to information about this project, including links to primary data, will be provided through the project website (www.plantreplication.net), GEO (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/), the NCBI's SRA (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sra), Gramene (http://www.gramene.org/), MaizeGDB (http://www.maizegdb.org/), and TAIR (http://www.arabidopsis.org/).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Before each cell division, a cell must produce two identical copies of its genome and restore the correct modifications to its DNA and chromatin. At the onset of this project, nearly all of our knowledge about genome replication in higher eukaryotes was from studies in animals. These studies showed replication is a temporally ordered process, occurring in large domains in which multiple origins “fire” in concert. In contrast, much less was known about DNA replication in plants. Although there are many similarities between molecular processes in plants and animals, there are also many important differences between the two kingdoms, and we cannot assume that DNA replication programs in plants mirror those in animals.

This project developed novel strategies to examine plant DNA replication. We fed corn roots or Arabidopsis cells a thymidine analog (“EdU”) that permits fluorescent labeling of recently synthesized DNA, and combined this with flow cytometry to generate populations of nuclei in early, mid or late S phase. Labeled DNA in these staged nuclei was characterized by high resolution microscopy and high throughput sequencing to determine spatial and temporal patterns of replication. This new approach does not rely on chemicals or starvation to synchronize cell division, making it less susceptible to artifacts. Its robustness is underscored by the high level of reproducibility across bioreplicates. We also developed a new bioinformatic pipeline (“Repliscan”) to characterize replication timing patterns. The EdU-flow cytometry methodology and the Repliscan pipeline can be readily applied to other biological systems.

Our studies uncovered a complex temporal pattern of DNA replication in both maize and Arabidopsis, with euchromatin replicating in early and mid S phase and heterochromatin replicating late. We did not observe the large domains characteristic of mammalian DNA replication. However, microscopic analysis of maize nuclei revealed that spatial patterns of DNA replication differ between early and mid S phase. There are many EdU-labeled foci in both early and mid S-phase nuclei but early foci do not coincide with bulk chromatin while mid foci overlap bulk chromatin. (A similar spatial difference has not been reported in metazoans.) Our studies also showed that DNA in early-replicating chromatin is more accessible than DNA in mid-replicating chromatin. Together, these results support a model in which early replicating DNA occurs in loops extending from the chromosome core, which replicates during mid S phase. An unexpected feature of maize DNA replication is that transposable elements replicate throughout S phase, with the earliest replicating elements closest to genes. This is in contrast to animals, in which transposable elements replicate late with heterochromatin.

We also characterized replication initiation regions in Arabidopsis, exploiting the fact that DNA labeled by EdU at the very beginning of S phase must be near replication origins. This approach identifiedmore than 5500 initiation regions (“IRs”) dispersed across the Arabidopsis genome. The IRs represent a unique group of AT-rich sequences that are flanked by more GC-rich regions and are located primarily in intergenic regions. In contrast, metazoan origins are GC rich and associated with genes. However,Arabidopsis IRs and metazoan origins are both strongly associated with accessible chromatin, which is thought to be the defining feature of origins in higher eukaryotes. 

The project also analyzed the three possible forms of DNA methylation in Arabidopsis cells. The level of the CHH form, which is directed by 24-nt small RNAs, is extremely low in rapidly dividing cells, where small RNA is mainly in the 21-nt size class. When Arabidopsis cells stop dividing, CHH methylation is restored, along with 24-nt small RNA. In contrast, CG and CHG methylation levels are maintained in dividing and arrested cells. However, CG methylation is transiently asymmetric during S phase and rapidly restored during each cell division, while CHG methylation remains asymmetric throughout the cell cycle. These results demonstrated that DNA methylation dynamics in Arabidopsis depend on sequence context and cell cycle status.

This project has begun to fill the gap in our understanding of plant DNA replication. It produced the first whole genome profiles for replication timing and initiation regions in plant systems. The studies in maize are the first to characterize a replication program during development of a multicellular organ in a eukaryote. The resolution of the Arabidopsis experiments is significantly greater than previously published studies and sets a new standard for studying replication timing programs. The project identified many similarities and some important differences between DNA replication in the plant and animal kingdoms. It led to the development of new strategies for studying and analyzing DNA replication and its relationship to gene expression, the epigenome, and chromatin structure. The project provides a strong basis for future studies that relate DNA replication and chromatin to developmental and phenotypic outcomes in plants.
